gen.metadata.title: Metamaterial array based meander line planar antenna for cube satellite communication
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and analyze a metamaterial-inspired meander line planar patch antenna for CubeSat communication that can be integrated with a 2U CubeSat structure and onboard subsystems (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve wide impedance bandwidth and stable gain (p. 7); Achieve a compact antenna design that fits within the 2U CubeSat body (p. 1); Enhance antenna gain and efficiency while maintaining frequency stability (p. 1); Ensure compact dimensions and ease of fabrication (p. 7); Verify the antenna's performance through simulation and experimental testing (p. 1); Verify the antenna's performance in a real CubeSat environment (p. 7)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of the antenna's performance in different CubeSat configurations and environments (p. 1); Investigate the performance of the antenna in different CubeSat configurations and orbits (p. 10)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the proposed antenna in CubeSat missions for command, tracking, and data downlink applications (p. 10); Further optimization of the antenna design for improved performance and reliability (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a compact and efficient UHF planar patch antenna for CubeSat communication systems, addressing the challenges of size, performance, and integration with the satellite structure (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a metamaterial-inspired meander line antenna be designed to fit within the constraints of a 2U CubeSat while maintaining high performance? (p. 1); How can a UHF antenna be designed to meet the size and performance requirements of CubeSats? (p. 7); What are the key design parameters and performance metrics of the proposed antenna? (p. 1); What are the key performance metrics of the proposed antenna when integrated with a CubeSat structure? (p. 7)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: 3D electromagnetic simulator CST Microwave Studio Suite 2019 (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The proposed antenna outperformed other designs in terms of size, gain, and efficiency (p. 10)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Metamaterial-inspired meander line planar patch antenna (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers Duroid 5880 (εr = 2.2, tan δ = 0.0009, h = 1.575 mm) (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: A Numerical Procedure to Design a UWB Aperture-Coupled Microstrip Antenna Suitable for Space Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To develop a design procedure for a dual-polarized ultra-wideband ACMA suitable for CubeSat applications, with a focus on minimizing construction complexity and costs (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve good agreement between simulation and measurement results (p. 11); Develop a simple layered structure without inter-layer interconnects (p. 11); Ensure the design is suitable for large-scale production by minimizing construction complexity (p. 1); Design an ACMA with a fractional bandwidth > 40%, return loss > 10 dB, and polarization purity and isolation > 25 dB (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Further investigation into the impact of manufacturing imperfections and material properties (p. 9); Explore the use of different materials and manufacturing techniques to further optimize performance and cost (p. 1); Investigate the application of the design procedure to other frequency bands (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the developed design procedure for creating ACMA for CubeSat applications (p. 1); Consider the use of simple multilayer structures without interlayer interconnections or inclusions to minimize costs (p. 1); Use the design procedure for cost-effective mass production of antennae for CubeSats (p. 11)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a dual-polarized ultra-wideband aperture-coupled microstrip antenna (ACMA) suitable for CubeSat Ka-band applications, with a focus on minimizing construction complexity and costs (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a dual-polarized ultra-wideband ACMA be designed for CubeSat applications with minimal construction complexity and cost? (p. 1); What design procedure can achieve the required performance metrics (fractional bandwidth > 40%, return loss > 10 dB, polarization purity and isolation > 25 dB) using simple technology? (p. 1); How can a simple layered structure without inter-layer interconnects be developed for dual-polarized ultra-wideband aperture-coupled microstrip antennae? (p. 11)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: 11.9 m × 5.6 m × 6.0 m anechoic chamber using the multi-probe system Starlab and other microwave facilities at MVG Italia (p. 8)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Ansys HFSS optimizer using sequential non-linear programming (SNLP) (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT6002 (ϵr = 2.94, tanδ = 0.0012) for dielectric 1, RO4003 (ϵr = 3.55, tanδ = 0.0021) for dielectrics 2 and 3 (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.substrate_m: Rogers RT6002 for dielectric 1, RO4003 for dielectrics 2 and 3 (p. 5)

gen.metadata.title: Design of CP, High-Gain, Single-Feed, and Single-Layer S-Band Patch Antenna for Small-Satellite Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To develop a compact, high-gain, circularly polarized microstrip patch antenna for the HORYU-IV nanosatellite S-band communication (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: To achieve an effective bandwidth of 2.73% from 2.2450 to 2.3075 GHz for 10-dB return loss and 3-dB AR bandwidth at 13 MHz (p. 6); To measure the gain and 3-dB AR beamwidth of the antenna prototype (p. 6); Maintain less than 3-dB axial ratio for the entire field of view (p. 1); Achieve a sufficient beamwidth for LEO satellite application (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of the antenna's performance under different environmental conditions (p. 6); Investigate the performance of the antenna in different environmental conditions (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Further testing and integration of the antenna with other small satellites (p. 6); Integrate the antenna with the satellite body using nonconducting glue (p. 5)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Traditional satellite communication systems suffer from high costs and large antenna sizes, making them unsuitable for small satellites. Microstrip antennas, while lightweight and low-profile, often have low gain and require circular polarization for orientation-related issues (p. 2)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a CP, high-gain, single-feed, and single-layer S-band patch antenna be designed for small-satellite applications? (p. 6); How can a compact, high-gain, circularly polarized microstrip patch antenna be designed for small satellite applications? (p. 2)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: Environmental and mechanical testing in the KYUTECH Laboratory of Spacecraft Environment Interaction Engineering (LaSEINE) (p. 6)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The antenna achieves higher gain and broader field-of-view coverage with low axial ratio compared to similar designs (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Right-hand CP (RHCP) waves in the Z > 0 half-spaces (p. 4)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Compact single-layer coaxial-probe-fed circularly polarized high-gain patch antenna (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers substrate with a relative permittivity of 2.2 (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Coaxial probe feed from the bottom (p. 3)

gen.metadata.title: Semi-analytical design of dual-mode resonant microstrip antennas with electrically small patch size and tilted CP angle for satellite-assisted IoV
gen.objectives.main_objective: To develop a semi-analytical design approach for dual-mode resonant microstrip antennas with electrically small patch size and tilted CP angle for satellite-assisted IoV (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Determine the upper bound of patch radius for electrically small antennas (p. 3); Deduce mathematical formulas to predict the flare angle and outer/inner radius ratio for approaching an electrically small radius (p. 1); Not mentioned; Design and validate dual-mode resonant microstrip antennas with different flare angles and substrates (p. 1); Design and validate dual-mode resonant MASPAs with variable CP angles (p. 3)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of the antenna's performance in different vehicular communication scenarios (p. 2); Not mentioned; Explore the application of the design approach to other frequency bands and substrates (p. 9)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; Further experimental validation of the antenna design in real-world IoV scenarios (p. 2); Use the semi-analytical design approach to design microstrip antennas for satellite applications (p. 9)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Limited understanding of how to design microstrip antennas with electrically small patch size and frequency scannable tilted CP angle for satellite-assisted IoV (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: Not mentioned; What are the performance metrics and practical applications of such antennas? (p. 1); How can a semi-analytical design approach be developed for dual-mode resonant microstrip antennas with electrically small patch size and tilted CP angle? (p. 1); How can electrically small, dual-mode resonant, wideband CP microstrip antennas be designed for IoV applications? (p. 2); What are the key parameters and methods for achieving variable CP angles in these antennas? (p. 2)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: Satimo’s Starlab near-field antenna measurement system (p. 6)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: MATLAB for eigen-root calculations, numerical simulation software (p. 3-4)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Compared to other reported tilted CP antennas, the proposed antennas exhibit a distinctive operation principle, wider tilted CP bandwidth, and larger tilted CP angle range with frequency scanning functionality (p. 9)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Tilted CP frequency scanning characteristic within the whole impedance bandwidth (p. 9)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: F4B substrate (ε_r1 = 2.65) with h_1 = 2 mm suspending on an air substrate (ε_r = 1) with h_2 = 3 mm (p. 7)

gen.metadata.title: High-gain S-band Patch Antenna System for Earth-observation Cubesat Satellites
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and validate a high-gain, circularly polarized S-band patch antenna system for earth-observing cubesats (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a compact size and low weight suitable for cubesat standards (p. 1); Ensure good impedance matching and radiation properties (p. 1); Allow for the integration of optical payloads (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Explore the impact of different feeding phase configurations on antenna performance (p. 4)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the designed antenna system for earth-observing cubesats (p. 4); Consider the flexibility of the design for different mission requirements (p. 4)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a high-gain, circularly polarized S-band patch antenna system for earth-observing cubesats, which must comply with size and weight constraints while ensuring good performance (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a high-gain, circularly polarized S-band patch antenna be designed for cubesats? (p. 1); What are the performance metrics of the designed antenna system? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: 9.0 m × 6.0 m × 5.6 m anechoic chamber with TDK IB-011 ferrite tiles and TDK IP-045C pyramidal absorbers (p. 3)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: EM simulations using Microwave Studio by CST (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Unidirectional with a −3 dB aperture of about 58.8° (p. 3)
esp.domain_results.return_loss: −15.05 dB for a single patch, overall system S11 well below −10 dB at 2.45 GHz (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: High-gain circularly polarized S-band patch antenna system (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Four rectangular patches with a 90° phase difference between orthogonal pairs (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: Reconfigurable S-Band Patch Antenna Radiation Patterns for Satellite Missions
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a reconfigurable S-band patch antenna system for CubeSats that can achieve different radiation patterns and polarizations (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Optimize the antenna design for operation at 2.45 GHz (p. 2); Analyze the effect of feeding signal phase on radiation patterns and polarization (p. 2); Design a feeding line with phase electronic control (p. 4)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the antenna system in different space environments (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the reconfigurable antenna system for CubeSats to achieve mission-specific radiation patterns and polarizations (p. 5)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a reconfigurable S-band patch antenna system to achieve different radiation patterns and polarizations for various CubeSat missions (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a single antenna system achieve different radiation patterns and polarizations for various CubeSat missions? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: 1° step rotating system in an anechoic chamber (p. 5)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: CST Microwave Studio and Microwave Office (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Directional with maximum radiation along the boresight with a -3 dB aperture of about 58° (p. 5)

gen.metadata.title: Microstrip Antenna Gain Enhancement using Multilayer Substrate and Superstrate Structure for Space-Based ADS-B Surveillance
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and optimize a high gain microstrip antenna for CubeSat applications using a multilayer substrate and superstrate structure (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Evaluate the performance of the initial microstrip antenna design (p. 2); Optimize the antenna design by adding a superstrate layer and increasing the substrate thickness (p. 2); Fabricate and measure the performance of the optimized antenna (p. 2); Increase the antenna gain (p. 7); Improve the return loss and bandwidth (p. 7); Maintain a compact form factor (p. 7)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of other superstrate designs for further gain improvement (p. 6); Long-term reliability testing of the antenna in space conditions (p. 6); Investigation of other superstrate designs and materials (p. 7)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integration of the antenna into CubeSat systems for real-world testing (p. 6); Further optimization of the antenna design for better performance (p. 6); Further optimization of the antenna design for better performance (p. 7)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a high gain antenna for space-based ADS-B surveillance to cover remote areas where ground-based systems are insufficient (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What is the impact of using a multilayer substrate and superstrate structure on the antenna's performance? (p. 1); How can the gain and bandwidth of an ADS-B antenna be improved for CubeSat applications? (p. 7); How can the gain of a microstrip antenna be enhanced for CubeSat applications? (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms previous works in gain performance (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: Fits within the Z-axis side of a 1U CubeSat (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Microstrip patch antenna with superstrate and additional substrate layer (p. 7)
esp.technical_specifications.superstrate: Circular patch identical to the microstrip antenna patch (p. 3)

gen.metadata.title: Miniaturized and Circularly Polarized Dual-Port Metasurface-Based Leaky-Wave MIMO Antenna for CubeSat Communications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To propose a miniaturized MTS-based leaky-wave MIMO antenna optimized for CubeSat communication systems across microwave and millimeter-wave bands (p. 6)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Operate in three bands (3.75–5.25 GHz, 6.4–15.4 GHz, and 22.5–30 GHz) (p. 1); Support frequency- or phase-dependent beamsteering without mechanical parts (p. 1); Achieve a gain of 12.5 dBi and a radiation efficiency of 85% (p. 1); Achieve high gain, radiation efficiency, and circular polarization (p. 6); Evaluate performance metrics such as gain, bandwidth, and return loss (p. 20); Not mentioned; Support high data rates and beamsteering abilities without electrical or mechanical sophistication (p. 6); Ensure reliable long-distance communication with low power consumption (p. 1); Ensure stable circular polarization (p. 20); Design a compact, dual-port MIMO antenna using a modified phased MTS with coffee bean-shaped arrays (p. 6); Achieve high gain and efficiency (p. 20)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the use of the proposed antenna in multi-satellite networks (p. 11); Investigate the thermal and radiation resilience of the antenna materials (p. 21); Explore the integration of the antenna with other space-constrained platforms such as UAVs and terrestrial IoT systems (p. 21); Study the nonlinear performance and dielectric breakdown behavior for higher power applications (p. 21); Investigate the long-term performance and reliability of the antenna in space conditions (p. 1); Not mentioned; Explore the integration of the antenna with other CubeSat components (p. 1); Explore the impact of different MTS configurations on antenna performance (p. 11)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the antenna into CubeSat communication systems for enhanced performance (p. 1); Integrate the proposed antenna design into CubeSat communication systems (p. 6); Integrate the antenna with onboard energy-harvesting systems or intelligent beam-forming ICs (p. 21); Conduct practical tests to validate simulation results (p. 1); Not mentioned; Conduct experimental validation to confirm simulation results (p. 11); Explore the potential for incorporating this antenna into next-generation CubeSat missions (p. 21)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: CubeSats require lightweight, compact, high-performance antennas that meet strict size, weight, and power (SWaP) constraints while sustaining solid performance in severe space conditions (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a miniaturized MTS-based leaky-wave MIMO antenna be designed for CubeSat communication systems? (p. 6); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna in CubeSat applications? (p. 20); Not mentioned; How can a metasurface-based leaky-wave MIMO antenna be designed to meet CubeSat communication requirements? (p. 1); What are the performance metrics and benefits of the proposed antenna design? (p. 6); What are the key performance metrics and design features that enhance the antenna's efficiency and reliability? (p. 1); How can a miniaturized antenna achieve high gain and efficiency while maintaining stable circular polarization? (p. 20)
esp.domain_methodology.performance_metri: ['Gain', 'Bandwidth', 'Return Loss', 'VSWR', 'Radiation Pattern', 'Radiation Efficiency', 'Axial Ratio', 'Sidelobe Level'] (p. 14, p. 18)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Full-wave simulation using CST Microwave Studio (or HFSS) (p. 18)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms previous studies in terms of compactness, frequency coverage, gain, and multifunctionality (p. 18)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Bidirectional at lower bands and more directional at higher bands (p. 16)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: Fits within the standard 10 × 10 × 10 cm³ CubeSat unit (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Miniaturized circular polarized dual-port MTS-based leaky-wave MIMO antenna (p. 20)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT 5880 (εr = 2.1, tan δ = 0.001, h = 1.5 mm) (p. 11)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Rectangular patch connected to a transmission line (p. 7)
